column4: Dec. 21 (CNA) The number of imported dengue fever cases in Taiwan that originated in Cambodia has increased sharply this year to 66 compared with eight in 2017
column5: a senior official at the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Friday.------Cambodia has also been the largest source of imported dengue fever cases in Taiwan this year
column6: said CDC Deputy Director-General Chuang Jen-hsiang (莊人祥).------Citing CDC data valid as of Dec. 20
column7: Chuang said the total number of imported dengue fever cases in Taiwan this year was 330
column8: with the three major sources being Cambodia (66)
column9: Vietnam (62) and the Philippines (56).------Last year the number of cases that originated in Vietnam was 104 and in the Philippines 39
column10: Chuang said.------He said the big jump in infections originating in Cambodia was due to an increase in Taiwanese visitors this year to the Southeast Asian country
column11: where dengue fever has been spreading.------According to international media reports
column13: 000 cases of dengue fever have been reported in Cambodia this year
column15: and 16 of those cases have been fatal.------The dengue fever outbreaks have occurred mostly in Cambodia’s capital Phnom Penh and in Siem Reap
column16: a resort town in northwestern Cambodia where the famous Angkor Wat religious monument is located
column27: and Sri Lanka are among the Asian countries on the CDC’s Watch list
column28: as part of its three-tier travel warnings.------According to Tourism Bureau statistics
column30: 522 Taiwanese traveled to Cambodia in the first 10 months of the year
column31: an increase of 16.69 percent from the 67
column32: 289 recorded in the same period of 2017.------http://focustaiwan.tw/news/asoc/201812210011.aspx------ ------(By Chen Wei-ting and Elizabeth Hsu)------Enditem/pc
